awd_titl_txt: Collaborative proposal: Workshop on ecological impacts of solar radiation management geoengineering; February, 2020; Port Jefferson, NY;  October, 2020; Minneapolis, MN
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop award will address the impacts of environmental geoengineering on the living systems of earth. Geoengineering is a set of activities deliberately designed to counter the impacts of environmental change. It has received increasing attention in the face of failure to limit inputs of greenhouse gases to the atmosphere. These ideas are highly controversial among both scientists and the general public. Nevertheless, many schemes for geoengineering have been proposed and some have been extensively studied using complex climate models. The best-studied scheme for geoengineering is solar radiation management, which would cool Earth's surface by increasing the albedo (reflectivity) of the Earth-atmosphere system, reducing incoming solar radiation. This geoengineering management option presents both known and unknown risks to the natural living world. Yet almost nothing is known about the potential impacts of implementation, continuation or termination on natural systems, their functions, and their biodiversity. The goal of the workshop is to develop a research agenda to understand and predict how the biodiversity and functioning of natural systems would be affected by solar radiation management. The workshop will develop information to inform policy and public discussion, provide knowledge to incorporate into teaching and outreach, and engage a diverse audience in discussions on the response of living systems to solar radiation geoengineering.

A major goal of this workshop award is to develop a framework that will enable understanding and predictions of how the biodiversity and functioning of natural systems would be affected by solar radiation geoengineering. Despite the growing literature of caution and strategies for managing an uncertain process with planetary-scale implications, there has been little to no research on the implications of geoengineering for ecological systems. The workshop will address how this geoengineering approach could change predicted effects of environmental change on natural systems. A major product of the workshop will be a research agenda that will lay out a series of high priority issues for research on ecological impacts, consider the challenges and discuss how they might be met, and initiate and publicize a research agenda for the wider relevant scientific communities. Such issues include: downscaling, estimating diversity for plants, birds, and amphibians in biodiversity hotspots or at critical sites for suspected range limitations/expansions, and connecting those data with climate projections for geoengineering scenarios. The workshop will support the collaboration of a group of ecologists and climate scientists, ranging from graduate students to senior academic and federal laboratory researchers, to develop a research agenda on the ecological impacts of this geoengineering approach. They will examine how natural systems would be impacted by the climate modification, in contrast to future anthropogenic environmental change. The proposed workshop would consist of two in-person meetings and regular electronic meetings before, during and after the in-person meetings. This collaborative team of highly interdisciplinary specialties will consist of atmospheric scientists and scientists studying a wide range of ecological areas, including researchers from additional disciplines to contribute to future research in this area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We convened a workshop in which scientists who study the ecology of organisms and ecological systems joined with atmospheric scientists who study climate and climate intervention to achieve several goals. When we began this undertaking, almost nothing was known about how solar radiation modification (SRM) would affect organisms in the natural world, were it ever to be implemented. First, we wanted to become much more familiar with each others’ work. Second, we wanted to develop a research agenda to prioritize what needs to be known about the relative risks and reduction in risks when climate intervention, particularly SRM, was compared with the risks and harm from climate change. Finally, we wanted to lay the groundwork for future collaborations between scientists in these different realms to begin to address these challenges. We also worked to include a diverse group of scientists, including early career scientists, at all stages of this project.

Some of our findings were:

  • There is a high likelihood that cooling from SRM would reduce dangers to organisms in many systems, including coral reefs, alpine, and tropical regions
  • SRM would not reduce other harms, such as that from ocean acidification for coral reefs
  • Projections of effects on precipitation are more variable and uncertain, and the potential for drought and seasonal changes in rainfall with SRM are crucial issues for natural systems
  • SRM has the potential for reductions in catastrophic intense rainfall events and flooding, which might have ameliorating effects on ecological systems, but too much is unknown to make good projections at present
  • Initiating SRM without very substantive reductions in carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions would have numerous unwanted impacts on natural system, and sudden termination of SRM in later decades without reduction in atmospheric greenhouse gasses would have catastrophic consequences for natural systems
  • Implementation of SRM after decades of climate warming, in response to catastrophic climate change, may expose organisms and ecological systems to unanticipated risks from sudden dramatic cooling, but also might ameliorate some risks
  • SRM would have large effects on forests in many parts of Earth, with feedbacks to climate; these effects might ameliorate damage to some living systems, but the  effects are largely unstudied and unknown. It is urgent to begin learning much more.
  • Better metrics of climate and climate change based more directly on organisms and ecosystem responses rather than the currently used proxy measures should be developed to improve our understanding of how they respond to climate change and potentially to climate intervention
  • Atmospheric scientists must become much more cognizant of work on climate change on living natural systems and the effects of potential climate intervention on them, and ecological scientists must become far more aware of current work on climate intervention in atmospheric science so that they can be “at the table” in discussions considering SRM consequences and possible implementation. This workshop has moved the needle forward on this.

The workshop participants met regularly in virtual meetings during the pandemic, and in person twice. We published scientific papers with the outcome of our discussions, and members of the working group gave many talks at scientific venues on the outcome of our deliberations. We concluded that there are both well understood and unknown risks, but also amelioration of risks possible for organisms in natural systems were climate intervention ever to be implemented, and have documented what those might be and where much more needs to be learned.
